pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 29, 2023
Holly Halabicky
Mission Ranch
9300 Lahring Road,
Gaines, MI, 48436
Re: License #: CI250410439
SI#: 2023C0000778SI
Dear Holly Halabicky:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI250410439
Licensee Group Organization: Prism Project
Licensee Designee: Sylvia Blythe
Chief Administrator: Holly Halabicky
Agency Name: Mission Ranch
Agency Address: 9300 Lahring Road
Gaines, MI 48436
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/10/2025
Capacity: 6
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
9/22/2023 10:30 AM Onsite Inspection Special Investigation Initiation
9/22/2023 10:30 AM Face to Face Interview
10/5/2023 10:45 AM Face to Face Interview
10/12/2023 10:00 AM Face to Face Interview
10/18/2023 1:00 PM Video Conference MDHHS Pre-Disposition
Meeting- no findings
10/20/2023 8:30 PM Face to Face Interview
10/23/2023 1:15 PM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & R 400.4109 Program statement.
Section Rule 109. (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following: (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
1

needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation About a month ago youth believed she was possibly sexually
assaulted because they woke up with blood in their vaginal area
and they were in pain. Youth would not provide staff with any
details. On 9/20/23, a staff member snapped youth's bra.
Investigation On 09/22/2023 an in person joint interview was completed with
Chief Administrator (CA) and Executive Director (ED) at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist was also present. She
reported Youth D has a history of reporting sexual abuse
allegations and then recanting. ED advised Youth D went AWOL
on 9/2/2023 by sneaking out of her window and was returned by
law enforcement. Upon return, Youth D denied any use of drugs
or alcohol while AWOL and denied any sexual abuse concerns.
CA reported Youth D has not made any prior reports of any type
of abuse by Mission Ranch staff. CA and ED advised of agency
policy that requires two staff coaches with the children at all times
and that staff must see at least one body part during bed checks
to confirm it is the actual youth. Both CA and ED deny any youth
have expressed concern regarding sexual abuse by staff. They
both also confirmed Staff 7 is a midnight staff and a safety plan
was implemented to not allow Staff 7 to have contact with the
youth alone. ED agreed to take Youth D to Hurley Hospital for an
exam.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with ED. The
DHHS specialist was also present. She reported she advised her
staff to contact 911 first if there is an emergency. If it is not an
emergency, staff are advised to contact administration staff first to
see if a call to 911 is necessary. Staff is directed to contact
administration if any issue arises.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist and Detective were also
present. Youth A reported not having a good relationship with
Youth D because she lied in the past. Youth A denied ever
inappropriately touching Youth D or wanting to have sex with her.
Youth A denied Youth D reported any sexual abuse by staff to her.
Youth A advised Youth C is her best friend and they instantly
clicked when she came to the agency. She confirmed that they
began writing romantic letters to each other and making plans for
their future together. Youth A reported she and Youth C did kiss
2

once in the laundry room where there are no cameras but denied
they have ever kissed in front of staff. On 10/12/2023 an in-
person follow up interview was held with Youth A at Mission
Ranch. Youth A denied Youth D advised her of any sexual abuse
that occurred by staff at the facility. She also denied Youth D told
her about staff coming into her room and snapping her bra.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 1 at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
denied hearing anything about concerns with other staff. She
confirmed being present a couple of weeks ago when Youth D
reported the relationship between Youth A and Youth C. Staff 1
reported she logged the information and advised administration.
Staff 1 denied being informed by Youth D about any sexual abuse
or mistreatment by other staff.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2
advised she has works third shift from 11pm to 7am. Staff 2
reported during night checks she monitors the youth in 15-minute
intervals and if she is not able to visually confirm that the youth is
in bed, she pairs with another staff and enters to room to confirm
as required by policy. She stated she has observed Staff 7 enter
Youth D’s room alone to confirm that she was there and indicated
it was because Staff 7 did not want to wait on the other staff. She
recalled Staff 7 was only in the room for seconds and denied
hearing her talk to the youth. Staff 2 further denied Youth D has
ever reported sexual abuse or disclosed any issues with staff. She
reported Youth D will consistently ask to call 911 to get out of
Mission Ranch. Youth D stated she doesn't want to be at the
facility, hates it "here", and that she wants to leave "this place".
Staff 2 denied Youth D ever gives a reason she hates it and wants
to leave. Staff 2 further reported Youth D will often request to go
to the hospital or to call paramedics with no reasoning. She
denied Youth D has ever requested to contact Child Protective
Services or police due to allegations of abuse or neglect. Staff 2
reported she often attempts to redirect and deescalate Youth D
and will offer her to call ED or CA if she is not successful and they
will inquire with youth about her needs and attempt to redirect or
deescalate her also.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 3. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 3 reported she mostly
works 3rd shift. Staff 3 denied being aware of any issues with
staff and their treatment of youth. She reported the only issue she
has had in the past is with Staff 7 falling asleep at work on one
3

occasion. She reported midnight staff does interval checks on the
youth during the shift. She denied having any staff refuse to
follow the two-person policy when needing to enter the bedroom
of youth. She further denied having knowledge of any staff not
following policy. Staff 3 denied Youth D has ever reported any
concerns or sexual abuse to her. Staff 3 reported there is a safety
plan to keep Youth A and Youth C from inappropriately engaging
with each other. She reported the letters were found in August
and they have not been allowed to sit by each other or be alone
with each other since that time. She reported conversations
between Youth A and Youth C have to include a staff to monitor
topics.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 4. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 4 denied youth have
complained about Staff 7 other than her being loud and waking
them up when cleaning at night. Staff 4 reported her only concern
is Staff 7 is sometimes late and does not communicate with other
staff. She denied concerns or knowledge of Staff 7 sleeping while
at work. Staff 4 reported recalling a time right after Youth D
returned from AWOL status, hearing Staff 7 in Youth D’s room
talking. Staff 4 reported hearing Staff 7 say “what” and thinks that
Staff 7 could be checking the window. Staff 4 denied that a
second person was in the room with Staff 7 at the time. She
reported Staff 7 was only in the room shortly and denied Youth D
ever made a complaint after that. Staff 4 denied Youth D has ever
reported any sexual abuse to her.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 5. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 5 denied she has ever
worked with Staff 7. She reported the youth complain Staff 7 is
loud at night. Staff 5 reported the team has been advised by ED
and CA to not address the supposed relationship between Youth
A and Youth C because it can cause them shame. They have
been advised only administration can address it. She reported
Youth A and Youth C are allowed to hold hands, however it has
be a way that is defined as “appropriate” in the policy manual.
The girls are not allowed to cross or intertwine their fingers in a
hold because this could suggest or be considered romantic.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Security
Officer. The DHHS specialist was also present. She denied
Youth D ever reported anything "serious" to her and denied that
she reported any type of sexual abuse.
4

On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with CA. The
DHHS specialist was also present. CA denied Youth D reported
any sexual abuse. CA reported administration and staff do up to
60 minutes of searching the property prior to calling police if a
child runs away. CA confirmed Youth A and Youth C have been
discovered to be in a relationship after they went AWOL together.
A safety plan was put into place to keep them apart and monitor
them, until recently when a step-down safety plan was made. Now
they have to have a staff member between them for conversations
and have to sit across the table from one another. CA reported
they are not allowed to touch and staff will separate them if this
happens. CA denied staff was told to not address any interaction
or relationship between Youth A and Youth C.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 6. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 6 denied any concerns
working with Staff 7. She denied ever seeing or having
knowledge of Staff 7 entering bedrooms without a second staff.
She further denied ever seeing or hearing that Staff 7 was sleep
while on shift. She also denied hearing complaints about Staff 7
from the youth. She denied Youth D has ever advised her of any
sexual abuse or not being allowed to make phone calls.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth B. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Youth B reported she and
Youth D have an issue with each other because Youth A is always
talking “crap”. Youth B denied Youth D has ever reported any
sexual abuse to her. Youth B reported the staff are good and
follow up on the needs of all the youth. She denied ever seeing
any staff sleep at work on the midnight shift. She reported she is
always allowed to make phone calls when she requests. Youth B
denied Youth A and Youth C are allowed to hold hands. She
denied having knowledge of any staff going into Youth D’s room at
night.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Admin 1 at
Mission Ranch. She denied Youth D has ever reported to her
anything about being sexually abused or a staff snapping her bra
strap. She denied youth are not allowed to make calls outside of
policy guidelines. Admin 1 reported the only time youth are
refused a phone call is if they are screaming and acting out of
control. Once the youth is calmed down enough to hold a
conversation, they are then allowed to make a phone call.
On 10/12/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 7 at
Mission Ranch. She advised she works midnight shift. Staff 7
5

confirmed once on her shift she went into the bedroom of Youth D
without another staff present. She recalled she was working with
Staff 2 and she entered the youth’s bedroom without the other
staff because she was not moving fast enough. Staff 7 reported
this occurred a couple days after Youth D had went AWOL, so she
was anxious and wanted to make sure she was in her room. She
reported she was only in the room for seconds and denied
touching or saying anything to Youth D while in the room. Staff 7
reported Youth D usually sleeps through the night and does not
get up. She reported sometimes Youth A will get up, get a snack
and return to bed. Staff 7 denied she has been in the room of
Youth D talking to her at night. She reported the only time she
has spoken to Youth D is to compliment her on her artwork. She
further denied going into the room of Youth D and snapping her
bra or touching her in anyway. Staff 7 denied Youth D has ever
reported any concerns to her about sexual abuse or any staff
member. Staff 7 also denied she has ever been sleep at work on
any shift.
On 10/12/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth C at
Mission Ranch. Youth C denied Youth D told her about any
possible sexual abuse or snapping of her bra that occurred since
she has been placed at the facility. Youth C further denied she
and Youth A are in a relationship. She acknowledged that she is
closer to Youth A than other youth at the facility.
On 10/12/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 8 at
Mission Ranch. Staff 8 denied knowledge of report of any sexual
abuse or snapping of bra by Youth D to staff.
On 10/20/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth D at
Mission Ranch. Youth D denied advising staff of her thoughts that
someone had come into her room and sexually assaulted her or
that she thought a staff had come into her room and snapped her
bra strap while she was sleep. Youth D confirmed that she
advised her case worker of this information via a letter she sent to
her. Youth D reported that she recalled waking up and feeling like
someone had touched her between her legs and that she was
bleeding. She denied that it could have been her monthly
menstrual cycle because she does not have them regularly and it
was not time. Youth D was unable to describe the person that she
believed to have entered her room. Youth D also reported that on
another day she recalled hearing someone in her room, which she
believed to have been Staff 2 or Staff 7. She stated the staff
snapped her bra strap and then left. She was unable to say why
she believed it to be Staff 2 or Staff 7. Youth D also advised that
6

she has requested medical attention and did not receive it. She
reports that ED wants to provide all of the medical treatment when
she would prefer getting treatment outside of the facility. A
specific example provided by Youth D involved an incident when
she said she requested to be seen by an OBGYN. She recalled
that ED offered to complete an exam as she is trained as a nurse
that can help when someone has been sexually assaulted, but
Youth D said she declined and requested to be seen by an
OBGYN instead and the agency refused to take her. Youth D
denied ever seeing or knowing of Staff 7 sleeping while at work.
Youth D further reported that she does not feel safe at the
placement because she does not belong there and she has told
her worker several times that she wants to go to another
placement.
On 10/23/2023 a telephone call occurred with Complainant. No
additional concerns were noted or reported.
Documents Reviewed
DHHS SW Contact - On 10/04/2023 I reviewed the DHHS SW contact
entered for interview of Youth D and ED by DHHS Specialist and
Detective. It stated Youth D confirmed she provided her caseworker a
letter on 9/26/23 stating that she did not feel safe at Mission Ranch and
that she has asked 100 times to be moved. She reported that “this
should have gotten her moved”. Youth D reported she documented in
the letter that she was sexually assaulted at Mission Ranch three to four
days before she ran away on 9/2/2023. Youth D reported she believes
she was sexually assaulted in the middle of the night on 9/28/2023 or
9/29/2023. She stated she woke up in the middle of the night with a
flashlight in her face. A person was standing next to her bed and put the
light in her face. She stated the person left within seconds of her waking
up and she could not tell who the person was. She reported the person
did not speak. Youth D said she went back to sleep and woke up the
next morning with a lot of pain in her vagina and dark wet blood in her
vagina. She reported it was not her menstrual cycle as she has not had
a period in 4 to 5 months due to her birth control. She reported the pain
continued for two days. She described the pain and the blood as being
similar to when she was previously sexually assaulted. Youth D denied
she felt anyone on her bed. Youth D reported she went for a walk the
next day and reported the pain, blood and suspicion of sexual abuse to
Admin 1. Youth D reported Admin 1 did not respond and did not offer
medical help. Youth D reported she asked to go to the hospital or to an
OBGYN and ED refused. She reported ED offered to do the exam
herself, but she refused because she was uncomfortable. Youth D
reported two of the youth in the program are in a romantic relationship,
make out in front of staff and the staff does not try to stop it. Youth D
reported she feels Youth A is forcing Youth C to be in a relationship with
her and staff does not do anything. Youth D reported she was asleep in
the early morning on 9/20/2023 and it was almost light outside. She
7

reported she was laying on her back and she felt someone snap her bra.
Youth D demonstrated how her bra was snapped but gave three
different examples. Youth D was questioned about the area where her
bra was snapped and she repeated that it was on her bra, but the area
changed each time. Youth D reported she believes Staff 2 or Staff 7
snapped her bra because they worked that night. She denied the
person said anything and indicated they were out of her room quickly.
Youth D reported that she tried to kill herself about a week after running
away on 9/2/2023. She reported that she took the blade out of a pencil
sharpener and then cut her wrists and neck with it. She reported that
she was bleeding and in pain but not being taken for an evaluation. She
stated she was told that she needs to manage her mental health. Youth
D also reported that she was denied an exam after DHHS was in the
building last week.
Mission Ranch Video Footage – Footage reviewed for August 29,
2023, and August 30, 2023, and no one is seen entered room of Youth
D. Footage reviewed for September 20, 2023, and Staff 2 is seen going
into Youth D’s room with flashlight and for about two seconds. No one
else is seen entering the bedroom of Youth D. Footage is reviewed for
September 21, 2023, and no one is seen entering bedroom of Youth D.
Mission Ranch Supervision Program Policy – Policy indicated
that it is the expectation of the Prism Project that all staff will engage in
active supervision at all times. This includes but is not limited to the
following: A. Having knowledge of the residents’ whereabouts at all
times is critical and is balanced with allowing the residents a certain
amount of privacy. As a resident is able to be more responsible and
dependable, the supervision becomes less frequent or necessary.
These decisions are made on a case-by-case basis, by the individual
resident’s care team and with the safety of the resident as the most
important deciding factor. B. When youth are transitioning from one
activity to another (including but not limited to school, meals, group
therapy, etc) the direct care staff will conduct a head count of the youth
to ensure that all youth are accounted for during the transition to class
each day. Headcount will be recorded for accountability. C. Staff will
observe residents for any unsafe behaviors throughout their shift.
Additional Findings relevant to 400.4109 Program statement
Midnight staff failed to follow agency policy requiring two staff
members to be in the bedroom area of youth during midnight
schedule.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2
advised she works third shift from 11pm to 7am. Staff 2 reported
that during night checks she monitors the youth in 15-minute
intervals and if she is not able to visually confirm that the youth is
in bed, she pairs with another staff and enters to room to confirm
8

as required by policy. She stated she has seen Staff 7 go into
Youth D’s room alone to confirm that Youth D was still there and
indicated it was because she did not want to wait on the other
staff.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with CA. The
DHHS specialist was also present. CA reported Youth D has
mentioned having suicidal ideations and when she does ED or CA
will be contacted. An ASQ suicide screening will be completed
and then a virtual call will be held with GHS. CA reported staff are
asked but not required to contact administration prior to calling
911 to help problem solve. She reported if there is a fire or suicide
attempt staff have been directed to call 911 first.
On 10/12/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 7 at
Mission Ranch. She advised she always works midnight shift.
Staff 7 confirmed that once on her shift she went into the bedroom
of Youth D without another staff present. She recalled she was
working with Staff 2 and she entered the youth’s bedroom without
the other staff because she was not moving fast enough. Staff 7
reported this occurred a couple days after Youth D had gone
AWOL, so she was anxious and wanted to make sure she was in
her room.
Documents Reviewed
Mission Ranch Bed/Night Check Policy – Indicates when doing
bed checks staff should be sure to actually see a body part (arm, leg,
head, face). If you do not see a body part, communicate with your
coworker - have them come to the bedroom door, you go in and pull the
covers back and make sure that the resident is in her bed while your
coworker stands at the doorway as a witness.
Mission Ranch Video Footage – On 9/20/2023 review of video
footage between 11pm and 7am documented that Staff 2 went into the
bedroom of Youth D without another staff person present for
approximately two seconds.
HR file of Staff 7 – Employee has disciplinary action for being tardy in
the form of documentation of a verbal reprimand and write ups for
vaping in the driveway and using profanity when talking about the youth.
Technical Assistance
The agency needs to review and revise AWOL policy to prevent delay in
Law Enforcement notification as policy currently allows up to 60 minutes
to allow for search of the youth on the property of Mission Ranch. The
large size of the ranch property is acknowledged, however immediate
notification once a youth is missing is critical to their safety and well-
being.
9

Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was not sufficient
evidence to determine non-compliance with licensing rule
4109(1)(c) relevant to lack of supervision that would allow
someone to enter the room of Youth D and sexually assault her.
There was no evidence to support that anyone has entered the
room of Youth D and sexually assaulted her or snapped her bra.
Video that was reviewed did not show any staff entering the room
of Youth D on any of possible days she reported. All staff
interviewed denied touching the youth inappropriately and law
enforcement also closed their case after the investigation.
However, at the conclusion of the investigation, there was
sufficient evidence to determine non-compliance with licensing
rule 4109 (1)(c) relevant to staff failing to follow the agency
supervision policy during the midnight schedule. Interviews of
staff revealed that staff violated policy and entered the bedroom of
Youth D during the midnight shift alone.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR# 2023C0000453, CAP Approved 07/18/2023
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section Rule 142. (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff failed to seek appropriate medical attention for youth and
staff failed to follow written policy in response to youth expressing
suicidal ideations.
Investigation On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Admin 1 at
Mission Ranch. Admin 1 denied youth are made to stay in their
room if they are suicidal.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 1 at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
denied that youth are not allowed to make phone calls or not
provided professional medical care.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at
Mission Ranch. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2
reported she is required to contact ED before making any other
phone calls and ED will call the police or paramedics if she feels
it’s necessary. Staff 2 reported because Youth D requested to go
to the hospital for a month straight in the past, staff was advised to
10

contact administrative staff prior to calling an ambulance or 911
for Youth D.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 3. The
DHHS specialist was also present. She reported that she has
never heard of a youth not being able to call 911 when asked.
Staff 3 reported that she is instructed to call administrative staff
prior to police unless it is an emergency.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 4. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 4 reported when Youth D
took the blade from the pencil sharpener, she cut her neck with it,
but it was not bleeding. She reported Youth D requested an
ambulance be called, but Staff 4 stated she contacted ED to have
her assess it first. Youth D demanded she be taken to the
hospital because she wanted to kill herself. ED completed an
online assessment with GHS who did not recommend a hospital
assessment but did recommend one to one monitoring. ED came
to the facility and treated the cuts. Staff 4 reported staff are
directed to first assess the situation, then call administration
unless it is an emergency. Staff 4 reported that she would have
called 911 if the youth would have been bleeding a lot.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 5. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 5 reported she was
trained to first call ED or CA to let them know of issue prior to
calling 911. Staff 5 stated this comes from the youth requesting to
go to the hospital once per hour. When needed, she reported that
a GHS mental health assessment will be held via Zoom.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with CA. The
DHHS specialist was also present. CA reported Youth D cut her
neck with a razor, and it did not have any blood and further suicide
protocol was followed. CA denied that Youth D has ever asked to
see a doctor or OBGYN and been denied.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 6. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 6 denied being trained to
call administration before contacting police. She reported that she
would likely call ED first if anything happened to make sure she is
responding appropriately.
On 10/05/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth B. The
DHHS specialist was also present. Youth B reported she has told
ED that she was suicidal before and she did not go to the hospital.
She reported she was placed on a 1 to 1 supervision and had staff
11

with her at all times. Staff B reported ED wanted to take care of
the issue instead of the hospital. Youth B reported one or two
months ago she was doing dishes and there were knives in the
sink. She reported telling staff that she could not do dishes
because the knives in the sink were a trigger for her. She recalled
she went to her bedroom and still engaged in self-harming
behavior. She stated a GHS virtual appointment was completed
and a recommendation was made for day treatment. Youth B
reported ED denied the day treatment and stated Youth B could
be treated at the facility instead. Youth B reported she recalled a
time after Youth D returned from being AWOL that she did not get
to go to the doctor as she requested.
On 10/12/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 8 at
Mission Ranch. Staff 8 denied youth are denied access to
phones, professional services and medical appointments. Staff 8
reported that in the event of an emergency, staff are to contact
administration to discuss next steps or if it is an urgent matter,
they will contact law enforcement, EMS or fire department.
On 10/23/2023 a telephone interview was completed with CA and
ED to follow up and discuss the information documented on the
forms provided for review. It was confirmed Youth D had been
expressing suicidal ideations during and after an AWOL episode
on 9/3/2023. The ASQ Suicide Screening tool completed by CA
on 9/5/2023 for Youth D had been modified to assess for “the last
five hours” instead of the original ASQ tool language of “the past
few weeks”.
Documents Reviewed
Review of SWC entered by DHHS Specialist – ED was
interviewed by DHHS specialist and Detective. ED denied the midnight
staff had ever been discipline for mistreatment physically, mentally or
sexually of youth. ED reported she offered an exam to Youth D when
she returned from her AWOL. She reported Youth D refused and asked
to go to an OBGYN. ED reported she assessed Youth D has just
recently been to the OBGYN and it was not time for an evaluation. ED
reported Youth D indicated she understood. ED further reported she did
not take Youth D to Hurley Hospital last week after the advisement of
DHHS Specialist because she misunderstood and did not realize she
needed to take her as the report of abuse was from over one month
ago. ED denied youth are not allowed to go to professional medical
appointments. ED denied being advised of any sexual assault of Youth
D or of any staff coming into her room and snapping her bra. ED
advised Youth D reported Youth A and Youth C were having a romantic
relationship and later romantic letters were found in their rooms. ED
advised that policy regarding relationships and residents youth touching
is enforced by all staff. ED denied seeing the two youth kiss or touch
12

each other inappropriately. She further stated staff would not allow that
behavior. ED reported positive relationships are taught in group therapy
with the youth. ED reported that Youth D had an appointment with GHS
(a mental health provider) after she took apart the pencil sharpener and
made superficial cuts to herself with the blade. The cuts were not
bleeding and did not require a Band-Aid. ED reported GHS
recommended staff monitor Youth D for 24 hours. ED denied Youth D
was put in her room.
Review of 9/02/2023 Police Report #2321900240: Report
documented that Youth D went AWOL from Mission Ranch and was
knocking on door in the neighborhood asking about the nearest gas
station. Youth was advising that she had got into a fight with her
boyfriend, and he kicked her out of his car. Police located Youth D
walking down the road with a flashlight. She reported she was 18 years
old. Police told her that her story was inconsistent and asked if she was
lying. Youth D began to cry and admitted her identity and advised that
she had went AWOL from Mission Ranch. She stated she did not want
to return to Mission Ranch and would rather go to the hospital because
she was suicidal. Police documented that there were no injuries to her
body or wrist at this time. Youth D was taken back to Mission Ranch by
police and ED was advised of her suicidal comments. It was reported
that ED would petition youth for a medical evaluation.
Mission Point Suicide Ideation Policy – Policy indicates that if a
youth expresses suicidal ideations agency staff will do the following;
immediately contact the “on-call clinical staff member”, direct care staff
brief on-call clinician and follow directions of on-call clinician and stay
with the resident on 1:1 until the on-call clinician recommends another
course of action.
ASQ Suicide Risk Screening Tool – Screening tool completed on
9/5/2023 for Youth D documents that time frames for assessment were
modified by CA when using as an assessment tool. The tool time frame
standard is “the past few weeks” and it was modified to ask about “the
past 5 hours”.
Analysis After completion of interviews, it was determined the agency was
in non-compliance with licensing rule 4142 (a) as staff failed to
follow agency policy regarding medical treatment of youth. At the
conclusion of interviews, it was found that the ED failed to take
Youth D for medical evaluation as requested by the DHHS
specialist. The agency also failed to follow the steps outlined in
their policy when a youth is threatening suicide. Policy indicates
that staff will contact on-call clinical staff member for assessment
and interviews with the Chief Administrator and Executive Director
confirmed that this policy was not followed. In addition, after
review of the ASQ form being utilized by the agency, it was noted
that the agency was inaccurately using the form as the
13

assessment time frames were being modified which invalidates
the tool.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
11/14/2023
